comments.text:
Immediately after initiating the installer download, a user should be able to start selecting addons for automatic installation (once Firefox has completed installation). The user experience would likely be a part of the download page (while still surfing with Safari/Chrome/IE), and would show a short list of featured addons so as not to overwhelm the new user. Any addons checked would (somehow) be communicated to the browser on first launch and automatically downloaded/installed.

It's possible that a similar request has been made previously to allow the user to build their own Firefox download to include selected plugins. What makes this solution more desirable is that the user is already making forward progress with their download/install while selecting addons, and server scalability is less of an issue because the download itself remains static.

This functionality may be a good way to market our addons, which are great differentiators, to new users.

comments.text:
We are trying really hard to streamline the install process down to purely clicking an install button, and then without intervention the browser opens (stub installer does the download, the install completes without any required input, etc.)  I like the idea of getting new Firefox users shopping around for extensions, but I think it would be more effective to get them to do it post-install, after we've pulled off the conversion and once there is less going on.

New Firefox users aren't totally committed to using Firefox yet, so mentioning the possibility of extensions should help, but I'm worried that if we get too specific they might experience option paralysis.
